Editor’s choice paper Functionalized SBA-15 material with grafted CO2H group as an efficient heterogeneous acid catalyst for the fixation of CO2 on epoxides under atmospheric pressure Resmin Khatun a Piyali Bhanja b Rostam Ali Molla a Swarbhanu Ghosh a Asim Bhaumik b ⁎ Sk. Manirul Islam a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, University of Kalyani, Nadia, 741235, West Bengal, India Department of Chemistry University of Kalyani Nadia West Bengal 741235 India b Department of Material Science, Indian Association for the Cultivation of Science, Kolkata 700032, India Department of Material Science Indian Association for the Cultivation of Science Kolkata 700032 India ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Acid functionalized SBA-15 (AFS-1) has been synthesized through post-synthesis modification and the materials are thoroughly characterized. AFS-1 showed high reactivity for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from a wide range of epoxides and CO2 at atmospheric pressure. Carboxylic acid functionalized SBA-15 material AFS-1 has been synthesized through post synthetic route and the mesophase of the material has been characterized by powder X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy and N2 adsorption/desorption studies. Post-synthesis functionalization resulted high loading of carboxylic acid groups at the surface of highly ordered mesoporous silica. The material showed excellent catalytic activity for the production of cyclic carbonates from a wide range of epoxides in the presence of carbon dioxide (CO2) at atmospheric pressure and room temperature. The catalyst can be reused five times without significant loss of its catalytic activity. Keywords Acid functionalysed SBA-15 AFS-1 Mesoporosity Heterogeneous catalysis Cyclic carbonate derivatives Introduction CO2 is a green-house gas, which originates from activities of human and thus its accumulation is a serious threat to the environment. Fossil fuels are considered as the principal source of energy, which upon burning leads to carbon dioxide, which due to its high heat storage capacity is responsible for global warming and related atmospheric changes [1]. The reaction between CO2 and epoxides can lead to either polycarbonates or cyclic carbonates; both having considerable market value. CO2 is an attractive C1 feedstock because it is renewable, cheap and can substitute usually used poisonous C1 building blocks (phosgene). Since CO2 is a non-hazardous carbon source and abundant in nature and played key role in global warming, a great deal of attention has been paid in the recent years for its direct chemical fixation [1]. Several synthetic pathways have been invented to convert carbon dioxide into valuable organic compounds [2]. Among which a promising methodology is the production of cyclic five-membered carbonates from epoxide and CO2, which is very attractive in the context of economy and resource utilization [3]. Thus, CO2 fixation reaction is considered as one of the major environmentally hazardless chemical transformations [4]. Cyclic five-membered organic carbonates produced via the combination of epoxides and CO2 are the precursors material of polymeric compounds, electrolytes in polar aprotic solvents, rechargeable batteries, fine chemicals and intermediates in organic synthesis etc. [5]. Various heterogeneous and homogenous catalytic systems such as titanosilicates [6], ionic liquids [7], smectite [8], alkali metal salts alone [9], halostannanes [10], organic bases [11], mixed oxides [12], quaternary ammonium salt or phosponium salt [13], zeolite [14], crown ether [15], metal complexes [16] have been explored for this conversion. Soluble different alkali metal halides [17] are reported as a catalyst to synthesize cyclic five-membered carbonates. Homogeneous catalysts including metal complexes [18], alkali metal salts [19], bromine [20], alkali metal halides [21], ionic liquids [22], quaternary ammonium and phosphonium salts [23], etc. are also utilized for this reaction. But there are some disadvantages in these homogeneous catalysts such as they may simply be destroyed during the reaction time and cannot be reused. Although some heterogeneous catalysts are employed for this reaction, there are some drawbacks, such as addition of harmful organic solvent, requirements of high-pressure, drastic conditions of reaction and low activity of the catalyst [24,25]. From these points of view, it is highly desirable to utilize a reusable halogen-free highly reactive catalyst. Often, silica supported liquid phase catalysts (SLPC) are employed for this reactions where the halides of alkali metal are efficiently anchored on the surface of high surface area silica materials. Heterogeneous catalysts with active metal centers have been largely explored over last few decades for carrying out a wide range of chemical transformations [26]. Although metals in these catalysis are paramount to carry out these organic transformations but due to toxic nature of metals and their possibility of leaching these are not environmentally complete safe processes. So much attention has been paid for the development of catalysts devoid of metal and these materials are typically designated as organocatalysis [27]. Mesoporous silica based heterogeneous acid catalysts are very demanding in this context as their pores are in nanoscale range, they possess high BET surface area and outstanding host–guest combinations [28–30]. Such organically functionalized ordered mesoporous materials are largely explored in several frontline application areas, like catalysis [31], adsorption [32], ion-exchange [33], sensing [34] and so on. Rational grafting of the mesopore surface with reactive organic functionalities [35] can give rise to materials with enhanced catalytic properties. Herein, we have synthesized carboxylic acid grafted SBA-15 material AFS-1 employing post-synthetic functionalizations and the material has been utilized as a heterogeneous acid catalyst for the formation of cyclic carbonates using different kind of epoxides in the presence of carbon dioxide at atmospheric pressure and room temperature. Experimental section Synthesis of-CO2H functionalized SBA-15 (AFS-1) Mesoporous SBA-15 has been synthesized through a previously reported procedure [36]. Then 0.3g of SBA-15 material was stirred with 2.439mmol (0.54g) of 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (3-APTES) taken in 10ml of chloroform for 12h at room temperature under inert atmosphere. Then the solid product was filtered and washed with chloroform and dichloromethane successively. Resulting white solid product was dried in air. Then 4mmol (0.45g) 4-formyl benzoic acid was dispersed in 20ml methyl alcohol and entire 3-aminopropyl functionalized SBA-15 was mixed with this solution. After that the mixture was refluxed at 333K temperature for 6h. Finally the product was separated by filtration. Remaining un-reacted carboxylic acid was removed from the solid product AFS-1 by repeated washing with hot methanol and ultimately dried under vacuum. Characterization of AFS-1 material X-ray diffraction The small-angle powder X-ray diffraction patterns of acid functionalised mesoporous silica AFS-1 is shown in Fig. 1 . During functionalization of SBA-15 with organic moiety a steady reduction of the peak intensity is observed, however the periodicity of the 2D- hexagonal structure has been retained. Three diffraction peaks of high resolution can be obtained in the 2θ range 0.6–2.07 for this functionalized SBA-15 material. These reflections can be assigned to the (100), (110) and (200) diffractions for the two-dimensional hexagonal mesostructure [36]. Surface area measurement The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm of AFS-1 is shown in Fig. 2 . This isotherm can be classified to type IV according to the IUPAC nomenclature with a very high hysteresis loop of H2 type in the 0.5–0.9P/P0 range [37]. The step raise in the N2 uptake is attributed to the filling of mesopores. Further, large hysteresis loop corresponding to large mesopores of SBA-15 material is observed. The surface area of AFS-1 is 240m2 g−1. Pore size distribution of the sample is determined by using the BJH method and this is shown in the inset of Fig. 2. Calculated width of pure silica SBA-15 was 10.5nm whereas in case of AFS-1 the size of pore is contracted to ca. 4.9nm. These data are in excellent conformity with the widths of pore estimated through the TEM image analysis. Microscopic analysis Fig. 3 depicts the representative high resolution transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image of AFS-1. The uniform arrangement of the large mesopores are clearly observed throughout the spective specimens. The TEM image also implies that the AFS-1 has a highly ordered 2D-hexagonal structure, similar to that of the SBA-15 type mesoporous silica synthesized by using triblock co-polymers as template [36]. UV–vis DRS analysis: UV–vis DRS analysis: The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectrum of the COOH grafted SBA-15 material AFS-1 taking BaSO4 as reference is shown in Fig. 4 . The material showed two absorption bands, one strong absorption in 200–300nm could be attributed due to the n-π* transitions and a weak broad vibrational bands at 340–350nm could be attributed the ligand π-π* transition of the aromatic ring. FT IR spectra FTIR spectrum of the CO2H grafted AFS-1 material is shown in Fig. 5 . Peak at 1691cm−1 corresponds to the stretching frequency of the CO group. The peaks at 3413 and 1385cm−1 (hump) correspond to O-H stretching vibrations and the COH bending vibrations respectively. Further, the peak at 1642cm−1 could be attributed to the CN stretching frequency of organic moiety (Scheme 1 ). Catalytic activity CO2 fixation reaction is a potentially important conversion for the fruitful utilization of harmful CO2 into value added products. Carbonates are typically classified into organic and inorganic (metal) derivatives and organic carbonates can be further grouped as acyclic carbonates, polycarbonates and cyclic carbonates (Scheme 2 ). First, we checked conditions of the reaction, including the reaction time and the amount of Bu4NBr in order to optimize the product five-membered styrene carbonate (Table 1 ). Styrene carbonate obtained through the coupling of CO2 with styrene oxide has been selected as a model reaction. From Table 1 it is clear that among different amount of Bu4NBr used, 5mol% showed best conversion (entry 9). We have checked the influence of reaction time on yield of the product (Table 1, entries 1–10). The best result was obtained by carrying out the reaction in 5mol% of Bu4NBr at RT for 24h using 25mg of catalyst AFS-1 at 1 atmospheric pressure. For the lower amount of Bu4NBr, the reaction did not proceed completely resulting in lower yield of the product (Table 1, entries 4, 5, 8 and 10). The catalytic activities of SBA-15, 3-aminopropyl functionalized SBA-15 and AFS-1 are compared in Table 2 for the synthesis of styrene carbonate. The yield observed for SBA-15 and 3-aminopropyl functionalized SBA-15 (Table 2, Entry 1–2) was quite low under optimization conditions due to absence of acid functionalizations in those materials. But in acid functionalized AFS-1 96% yield of styrene carbonate was observed (Table 2, Entry 3). The COOH group present in AFS-1 surface activates the oxygen atom of epoxide rings through protonation, which helps the insertion of CO2 in epoxides and produce cyclic carbonate derivatives (Scheme 3 ). Under such optimization conditions of reaction, we have checked the activities of AFS-1 for the formation of cyclic carbonate via the CO2 fixation reaction of epoxides with various substituted functional group. Different epoxides, such as cyclohexene oxide, propylene oxide, styrene oxide, allyl glycidyl ether, epichlorohydrin and 1, 2-epoxy-3-phenoxy propane, which are aryloxy epoxides undergo CO2 fixation reaction forming cyclic carbonate derivatives. Most of the substrates could be easily transformed to organic five-membered cyclic carbonates with outstanding selectivity and high yield (Table 3 , entries 1–9). It was examined that electron-withdrawing groups (Table 3, entry 5) of terminal epoxides and electron-donating groups (Table 3, entries 2–4 and 6–8) of the epoxides could be converted to the organic five-membered cyclic carbonates with more or less quantitative yields within 20–24h under 1atm pressure of CO2 at room temperature. Even at high CO2 pressure (10atm) yield of cyclic carbonate did not changed much. In Scheme 3 we have proposed a mechanism for the fixation of CO2 over epoxides using AFS-1 catalyst. Bronsted acidic sites due to the presence of CO2H sites could facilitate the protonation of epoxide oxygen, whereas basic sites due to the imine-N facilitate the activation of CO2 molecules. Thus, AFS-1 surface catalyzes efficiencly in this CO2 fixation reaction for the synthesis of cyclic five-membered carbonates (Scheme 3). AFS-1 coordinates with epoxide to produce a halo-alkoxide. Insertion of CO2 into halo alkoxide bond occurred thereby leading to produce an intermediate which undergoes ring-closer to synthesize the cyclic carbonate and generate the onium halide again. The tetrabutylammonium bromide (Bu4NBr) played a second role in the case of reactions catalyzed by AFS-1 by producing Bu3N in situ. The reaction of tributylamine with the CO2 is happened to generate a zwitterionic carbamate. This zwitterionic carbamate is stabilized by making coordination with the COOH group of AFS-1. The formation of key carbonate step takes place intra-molecularly rather than inter-molecularly due to the high reactivity of AFS-1. Recyclability of AFS-1 material The reusability of the AFS-1 material was checked in the synthesis of cyclic carbonate through the reaction of epoxides and CO2. After the reaction the reaction mixture was centrifuged to remove the catalyst. Then the used AFS-1 was washed with hot methyl alcohol and finally desiccated under vacuum for 6–7h, before proceeding to the next reaction cycle. It is seen from Fig. 6 that the acid functionalized AFS-1 can be easily recovered and recycled for five reaction cycles without losing any significant catalytic activity. From this it is clear that the AFS-1 material behave entirely as a heterogeneous catalyst. Catalysis procedure Materials 3-APTES and 4-formylbenzoic acid were collected from Sigma Aldrich. All epoxides were taken from the brand of Aldrich Chemicals. All solvents and also reagents were distilled through standard process and dried up. TLC was performed with silica gel 60F254 by handling marketable plates (MERCK). Typical procedure for organic five-membered cyclic carbonate synthesis at 1atm pressure using AFS-1 catalyst Styrene oxide (5mmol), catalyst AFS-1 (50mg) and Bu4NBr (26.7mg, 0.083mmol) were kept in a 25ml R.B flask which is fitted with a magnetic stirrer bar. The R.B was also fitted with a cork of rubber penetrated with a balloon which is deflated. Then this mixture of reaction was vigorously stirred up to 24h at room temperature. The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC and the formation of cyclic carbonate was confirmed by Gas Chromatography (GC) by comparing with the authentic sample. Standard synthesis of cyclic carbonate derivatives at 10atm pressure A representative epoxide (5mmol), AFS-1 catalyst (50mg) and Bu4NBr (0.083mmol, 26.7mg) were taken in a 25ml R.B flask. Then the mixture was kept in a stainless steel pressure reactor at room temperature. Further the reaction mixture was continuously stirred at room temperature up to 24h. Conclusion In conclusion, we have synthesized acid functionalized mesoporous SBA-15 material and its catalytic activity for the preparation of cyclic carbonate derivatives from different epoxides and carbon dioxide under atmospheric pressure and standard temperature is explored. The mesoporous acid functionalised SBA-15 material have ordered porous structure, good pore wall stability, high thermal stability and high BET surface area. We have successfully used this material to produce cyclic carbonate derivatives from different epoxides and carbon dioxide under mild conditions such as atmospheric pressure. Use of these recyclable catalysts makes this process cost effective, environmentally benign, hazardless and green. The catalyst was reused and recycled for five consecutive cycles with catalytic activity of fixed range. High recycling efficiency, smooth reaction at 1 atmospheric pressure, general applicability, mild reaction temperature, high yield of products over acid functionalized SBA-15 suggested future potential of this CO2 fixation reaction for the cost effective and green synthesis of a wide range of value added fine chemicals. coredata.dc:description: Carboxylic acid functionalized SBA-15 material AFS-1 has been synthesized through post synthetic route and the mesophase of the material has been characterized by powder X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy and N2 adsorption/desorption studies. Post-synthesis functionalization resulted high loading of carboxylic acid groups at the surface of highly ordered mesoporous silica. The material showed excellent catalytic activity for the production of cyclic carbonates from a wide range of epoxides in the presence of carbon dioxide (CO2) at atmospheric pressure and room temperature. The catalyst can be reused five times without significant loss of its catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Functionalized SBA-15 material with grafted CO2H group as an efficient heterogeneous acid catalyst for the fixation of CO2 on epoxides under atmospheric pressure
